query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Imagini, chi bene intender cupe 2 quel ch’i’ or vidi—e ritegna l’image, 3 mentre ch’io dico, come ferma rupe—,
query.error: **English:** 1 Imagine, if you can truly understand 2 what I saw then—and hold the image, 3 as I speak, like a solid rock—,
query.result: 1 Wena ðu ðe wel cunne ongietan deope 2 ðæt ðe ic ða geseah—and geheald ða gesyhðe, 3 swa swa ic secge, swa steapne stan—,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 quindici stelle che ’n diverse plage 5 lo ciel avvivan di tanto sereno 6 che soperchia de l’aere ogne compage;
query.error: **English:** 4 fifteen stars that in different regions 5 enliven the sky with such serenity 6 that they surpass every part of the air;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 imagini quel carro a cu’ il seno 8 basta del nostro cielo e notte e giorno, 9 sì ch’al volger del temo non vien meno;
query.error: **English:** 7 imagine that chariot whose axle 8 spans our sky both night and day, 9 so that it does not wane as the pole turns;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 imagini la bocca di quel corno 11 che si comincia in punta de lo stelo 12 a cui la prima rota va dintorno,
query.error: **English:** 10 imagine the mouth of that horn 11 that begins at the tip of the axis 12 around which the first wheel turns,
query.result: 10 wena ðu ðæs hornes muð ðe onginð æt ðæs stelan ende 11 ðæs ðe ðæt forma hweol ymb cyrreð, 12 habban geworht twegen tacnu on ðam heofone,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 aver fatto di sé due segni in cielo, 14 qual fece la figliuola di Minoi 15 allora che sentì di morte il gelo;
query.error: **English:** 13 having made two signs of itself in the sky, 14 like the daughter of Minos did 15 when she felt the chill of death;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 e l’un ne l’altro aver li raggi suoi, 17 e amendue girarsi per maniera 18 che l’uno andasse al primo e l’altro al poi;
query.error: **English:** 16 and the one having its rays in the other, 17 and both turning in such a way 18 that one went before and the other after;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 e avrà quasi l’ombra de la vera 20 costellazione e de la doppia danza 21 che circulava il punto dov’ io era:
query.error: **English:** 19 and it will have almost the shadow of the true 20 constellation and of the double dance 21 that circled the point where I was:
query.result: 19 steorran gesomnunge and ðære twyfealdan dancinge 20 ðe ymbcerde ðone stede ðær ic wæs: 21 forðæm hit is swa feor fram ure gewunan,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 poi ch’è tanto di là da nostra usanza, 23 quanto di là dal mover de la Chiana 24 si move il ciel che tutti li altri avanza.
query.error: **English:** 22 since it is as far beyond our experience, 23 as the sky that surpasses all others 24 moves beyond the movement of the Chiana.
query.result: 22 siððan hit is swa feor fram ure gewunan, 23 swa swa fram ðæs wæteres gecyrre ðe Chiana hatte, 24 swa hweorfeð se heofon ðe ealle oðre oferstígeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Lì si cantò non Bacco, non Peana, 26 ma tre persone in divina natura, 27 e in una persona essa e l’umana.
query.error: **English:** 25 There they sang not Bacchus, not Paean, 26 but three Persons in divine nature, 27 and in one Person it and the human.
query.result: 25 Þær ne song man Bacchus ne Pæana, 26 ac ðreo hadas on anre godcundre gecynde, 27 and on anre anlicnesse hit and ðæt mennisce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Compié ’l cantare e ’l volger sua misura; 29 e attesersi a noi quei santi lumi, 30 felicitando sé di cura in cura.
query.error: **English:** 28 The song and its measure came to an end; 29 and those holy lights awaited us, 30 rejoicing among themselves from care to care.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Ruppe il silenzio ne’ concordi numi 32 poscia la luce in che mirabil vita 33 del poverel di Dio narrata fumi,
query.error: **English:** 31 The harmonious gods broke their silence, 32 after the light in which you narrated 33 the wondrous life of God's poor man.
query.result: 31 Bræcon ða stilnesse on ðæm geþwæran godum 32 siððan ðæt leoht on ðam ðu wundra lif 33 ðæs earman Godes sægdest.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 e disse: «Quando l’una paglia è trita, 35 quando la sua semenza è già riposta, 36 a batter l’altra dolce amor m’invita.
query.error: **English:** 34 and said: "When one straw is threshed, 35 when its seed is already stored, 36 sweet love invites me to thresh the other.
query.result: 34 and cwæð: "Þonne an ceaf bið ðroscen, 35 and his sæd bið gegearwod, 36 ðonne me ðæt oder ðurh swetne lufe ðrescan tiht."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Tu credi che nel petto onde la costa 38 si trasse per formar la bella guancia 39 il cui palato a tutto ’l mondo costa,
query.error: **English:** 37 You believe that in the breast from which the rib 38 was drawn to form the lovely cheek 39 whose palate cost the whole world so dear,
query.result: 37 ðu gelyfst ðæt on ðæm breoste ðanon ðæt rib 38 wæs atogen to ðære fægeran wlite 39 ðæs swæcc ðe eallum middangearde costede,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 e in quel che, forato da la lancia, 41 e prima e poscia tanto sodisfece, 42 che d’ogne colpa vince la bilancia,
query.error: **English:** 40 and in that which, pierced by the lance, 41 both before and after gave such satisfaction 42 that it outweighs every sin in the balance,
query.result: 40 and on ðæm ðe ðurh ða wunde ðæs spere, 41 ægðer ge ær ge siððan swa fela gefylde, 42 ðæt hit ælce gylt oferwægð on ðære wage,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 quantunque a la natura umana lece 44 aver di lume, tutto fosse infuso 45 da quel valor che l’uno e l’altro fece;
query.error: **English:** 43 as much light as is permitted to human nature 44 was infused by that power which made both the one and the other; 45 and therefore look at what I said above,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 e però miri a ciò ch’io dissi suso, 47 quando narrai che non ebbe ’l secondo 48 lo ben che ne la quinta luce è chiuso.
query.error: **English:** 46 when I related that the good which is enclosed 47 in the fifth light had no second.
query.result: 46 and forðæm beheald ðæt ðe ic sæde ær, 47 ða ic sæde ðæt næfde ðone æfterran 48 ðæt god ðe on ðære fiftan leohte belocen is.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Or apri li occhi a quel ch’io ti rispondo, 50 e vedräi il tuo credere e ’l mio dire 51 nel vero farsi come centro in tondo.
query.error: **English:** 49 Now open your eyes to what I answer you, 50 and you will see your belief and my words 51 become true, like a center in a circle.
query.result: 49 Nu opena ðine eagan to ðæm ðe ic ðe andwyrde, 50 and ðu gesyhst ðinne geleaffulnesse and mine spræce 51 on ðæm soðan weorðan swa middel in ymbhwyrfte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Ciò che non more e ciò che può morire 53 non è se non splendor di quella idea 54 che partorisce, amando, il nostro Sire;
query.error: **English:** 52 That which does not die and that which can die 53 is nothing but the splendor of that idea 54 that our Lord brings forth, loving;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 ché quella viva luce che sì mea 56 dal suo lucente, che non si disuna 57 da lui né da l’amor ch’a lor s’intrea,
query.error: **English:** 55 because that living light which so warms me 56 from its shining, which is not separated 57 from it nor from the love that unites them,
query.result: 55 forðæm seo lybbende leoht þe swa me hylt 56 of his leoman, þe ne bið aslacen 57 of him ne of þære lufe þe him tosomne gæð,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 per sua bontate il suo raggiare aduna, 59 quasi specchiato, in nove sussistenze, 60 etternalmente rimanendosi una.
query.error: **English:** 58 through its goodness gathers its radiance 59 as if reflected, into nine subsistences, 60 remaining eternally one.
query.result: 58 ðurh his godcundnysse his leoman gædreð, 59 swilce on spegele, on nigon gesceafta, 60 ecelice wuniende an.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Quindi discende a l’ultime potenze 62 giù d’atto in atto, tanto divenendo, 63 che più non fa che brevi contingenze;
query.error: **English:** 61 Then it descends to the ultimate powers, 62 down from act to act, becoming so much, 63 that it does nothing but brief contingencies;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 e queste contingenze essere intendo 65 le cose generate, che produce 66 con seme e sanza seme il ciel movendo.
query.error: **English:** 64 and these contingencies I mean to be 65 the generated things, which the heavens produce 66 with seed and without seed, as they move.
query.result: 64 and ða gesceaftas ic mæne beon 65 ða geworhtan ðing, ðe ða heofonas wyrcað 66 mid sæde and butan sæde, swa hi stiriað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 La cera di costoro e chi la duce 68 non sta d’un modo; e però sotto ’l segno 69 idëale poi più e men traluce.
query.error: **English:** 67 The wax of these [planets] and what leads them 68 does not remain in one state; and therefore under the sign 69 ideal, now more and now less shines through.
query.result: 67 Þæs weox and se ðe hit lædeð 68 ne stent on anum men; and forðæm under ðam tacne 69 idealum ðonne ma and læs scineð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Ond’ elli avvien ch’un medesimo legno, 71 secondo specie, meglio e peggio frutta; 72 e voi nascete con diverso ingegno.
query.error: **English:** 70 And it happens that a single tree, 71 depending on its species, bears better and worse fruit; 72 and you are born with different talents.
query.result: 70 And hit gelimped ðæt an selfe treow, 71 æfter his cynne, wyrse and betere 72 wæstmas bære; and ge beoð acænned

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Se fosse a punto la cera dedutta 74 e fosse il cielo in sua virtù supprema, 75 la luce del suggel parrebbe tutta;
query.error: **English:** 73 If the wax were perfectly spread out, 74 and if the heavens were at their highest power, 75 the light of the seal would appear complete;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 ma la natura la dà sempre scema, 77 similemente operando a l’artista 78 ch’a l’abito de l’arte ha man che trema.
query.error: **English:** 76 but nature always makes it imperfect, 77 working in the same way as the artist 78 whose hand trembles as he works on his art.
query.result: 76 ac seo gecynd hit wyrcð symble unfull, 77 gelice wyrcende ðæm wyrhtan 78 ðe ðære handcræfte hafað hand ðe bifæð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Però se ’l caldo amor la chiara vista 80 de la prima virtù dispone e segna, 81 tutta la perfezion quivi s’acquista.
query.error: **English:** 79 Therefore, if warm love disposes and marks 80 the clear vision of the first virtue, 81 all perfection is acquired here.
query.result: 79 Forðæm ðe ðæt hât lufan ðone sciran gesihð 80 ðære forman mihte gedihteð and getacniað, 81 eall ðæt fulfremednes ðær bið geðeod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 sì ch’io commendo tua oppinïone, 86 che l’umana natura mai non fue 87 né fia qual fu in quelle due persone.
query.error: **English:** 85 so that I commend your opinion, 86 that human nature never was 87 nor will be as it was in those two persons.
query.result: 85 ðæt ic ðine geðoht geherige, 86 ðæt næfre monnes gecynd ne wæs 87 ne næfre ne bið swa swa he wæs on ðam twam.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Or s’i’ non procedesse avanti piùe, 89 ‘Dunque, come costui fu sanza pare?’ 90 comincerebber le parole tue.
query.error: **English:** 88 Now if I did not proceed further, 89 ‘Then how did this one become without equal?’ 90 your words would begin.
query.result: 88 Gif ic ða furðor ne fare, 89 ‘Hu ða ðeos wæs ðara ðinga gelic?’ 90 ðine word ða gewurðað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Ma perché paia ben ciò che non pare, 92 pensa chi era, e la cagion che ’l mosse, 93 quando fu detto “Chiedi”, a dimandare.
query.error: **English:** 91 But so that what does not appear may appear well, 92 consider who he was, and the reason that moved him, 93 when it was said "Ask", to ask.
query.result: 91 Ac ðæt ðæt uncuðe cuðe ðince, 92 ðencea hwa he wæs and hwæt hine dyde, 93 ða ða him wæs "Bidd" to biddanne gesæd.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Non ho parlato sì, che tu non posse 95 ben veder ch’el fu re, che chiese senno 96 acciò che re sufficïente fosse;
query.error: **English:** 94 I have not spoken so that you cannot 95 clearly see that he was the king who sought wisdom 96 so that he might be a sufficient king;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 non per sapere il numero in che enno 98 li motor di qua sù, o se necesse 99 con contingente mai necesse fenno;
query.error: **English:** 97 not to know the number in which the movers 98 of the heavens above are ennobled, or whether necessity 99 ever made necessity with contingency;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 non si est dare primum motum esse, 101 o se del mezzo cerchio far si puote 102 trïangol sì ch’un retto non avesse.
query.error: **English:** 100 not whether it is possible for the first motion to exist, 101 or whether it is possible to make a triangle 102 from half a circle that does not have a right angle.
query.result: 100 na hwæðer hit sy ðæt ðe forma stirung sy, 101 oððe ðe hit sy ðæt man mæge ðone healfan hring wyrcan 102 to ðrimfealdum ðingum swa ðæt he næbbe rihte hyrne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Onde, se ciò ch’io dissi e questo note, 104 regal prudenza è quel vedere impari 105 in che lo stral di mia intenzion percuote;
query.error: **English:** 103 Therefore, if what I have said and this you note, 104 that is royal prudence, that you learn to see 105 where the arrow of my intention strikes;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 e se al “surse” drizzi li occhi chiari, 107 vedrai aver solamente respetto 108 ai regi, che son molti, e ’ buon son rari.
query.error: **English:** 106 and if you direct your clear eyes to the “arose,” 107 you will see that it refers only 108 to kings, who are many, and good ones are rare.
query.result: 106 and gif ðu ðine beorhtan eagan to ðæm “aros” gerihte, 107 ðu gesihst ðæt hit hæfð anfealdlice gesceaft 108 wið cyningas, ðe sind manege, and ða godan sind seldcwene.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Con questa distinzion prendi ’l mio detto; 110 e così puote star con quel che credi 111 del primo padre e del nostro Diletto.
query.error: **English:** 109 With this distinction, take my statement; 110 and thus it can stand with what you believe 111 about the first father and our Beloved.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 E questo ti sia sempre piombo a’ piedi, 113 per farti mover lento com’ uom lasso 114 e al sì e al no che tu non vedi:
query.error: **English:** 112 And let this always be a weight upon your feet, 113 to make you move slowly like a weary man 114 and to the yes and the no that you do not see:
query.result: 112 And þis þe sy æfre bleo to fotum, 113 to macienne þe slawlic swa werig mann 114 and to þam gea and þam nane þe þu ne gesyhst:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 ché quelli è tra li stolti bene a basso, 116 che sanza distinzione afferma e nega 117 ne l’un così come ne l’altro passo;
query.error: **English:** 115 for he is rightly placed among the fools 116 who affirms and denies without distinction 117 in the one case as in the other;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 perch’ elli ’ncontra che più volte piega 119 l’oppinïon corrente in falsa parte, 120 e poi l’affetto l’intelletto lega.
query.error: **English:** 118 because of which he often finds 119 that the common opinion leans toward the false side, 120 and then his intellect is bound by his affection.
query.result: 118 for þam he ongægn cymeð þæt gelome hwyrfeð 119 þone geleaffullican andan on lease healfe, 120 and syððan se wilna gebindeð þone andgit.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Vie più che ’ndarno da riva si parte, 122 perché non torna tal qual e’ si move, 123 chi pesca per lo vero e non ha l’arte.
query.error: **English:** 121 In vain more than once does one set out from shore, 122 because he does not return the same as when he sets out, 123 who fishes for the truth and does not have the skill.
query.result: 121 Oftor ðonne æne ðe man of ðære sælace gewiteð, 122 forðæm he ne cymeð swa he ær wæs, 123 se ðe fiscað æfter ðære soðfæstnesse and ðone cræft næfð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 E di ciò sono al mondo aperte prove 125 Parmenide, Melisso e Brisso e molti, 126 li quali andaro e non sapëan dove;
query.error: **English:** 124 And of this there are clear proofs in the world: 125 Parmenides, Melissus, and Bryson, and many others, 126 who went and did not know where;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 sì fé Sabellio e Arrio e quelli stolti 128 che furon come spade a le Scritture 129 in render torti li diritti volti.
query.error: **English:** 127 so did Sabellius and Arius and those fools 128 who were like swords to the Scriptures, 129 in twisting the right meanings.
query.result: 127 swa dyde Sabellius and Arrius and ða dysigan 128 ðe wæron swa swa sweord ðam gewritum 129 on ðam ðe hi rihte word awendon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Non sien le genti, ancor, troppo sicure 131 a giudicar, sì come quei che stima 132 le biade in campo pria che sien mature;
query.error: **English:** 130 Let people not be too sure yet 131 in judging, like those who judge 132 the crops in the field before they are ripe;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 ch’i’ ho veduto tutto ’l verno prima 134 lo prun mostrarsi rigido e feroce, 135 poscia portar la rosa in su la cima;
query.error: **English:** 133 for I have seen all winter long 134 the thornbush show itself rigid and fierce, 135 then later bear the rose on its summit;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 e legno vidi già dritto e veloce 137 correr lo mar per tutto suo cammino, 138 perire al fine a l’intrar de la foce.
query.error: **English:** 136 and I have seen a ship, once straight and swift, 137 sail the sea for its entire journey, 138 only to perish at the end, at the mouth of the river.
query.result: 136 and ic geseah ðone scip sumne georne 137 faran ðone sæ forð ofer his sið, 138 forwurðan æt ðam ende æt ðære ea m口ðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Non creda donna Berta e ser Martino, 140 per vedere un furare, altro offerere, 141 vederli dentro al consiglio divino;
query.error: **English:** 139 Let not Lady Bertha and Sir Martin believe, 140 that to see one stealing and another offering, 141 they can see them within the divine council;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 ché quel può surgere, e quel può cadere».
query.error: **English:** 142 for one can rise, and the other can fall."
query.result: 142 forðæm ðe se mæg arisan, and se mæg afeallan."
